newsitem.title: HONG KONG: China province state firms 96 profits fall 16 pct.
newsitem.headline: China province state firms 96 profits fall 16 pct.

text.p: State industrial enterprises in south China's Guangdong province notched up a combined net profit of 14 billion yuan for 1996, down 16 percent from 1995, local media reported on Monday.

Losses of 18 billion yuan in 1996 by the province's state-owned firms were offset by higher gross profits, the Shenzhen-based Investment Herald weekly said. It did not give a size for the gross profits.

The newspaper said loss makers were mostly firms set up in the 1960s with backward facilities and which suffered in the 1990s from cut-throat competition caused by so-called blind investments that were made without consideration of risk.
The newspaper attributed the earnings decline to increased tax payments, and finance-related and welfare costs.
The province's state industrial firms paid 27.37 billion yuan in tax in 1995, up 90 percent from 1990, it said.
Tax rates generally rose after China reformed its taxation system in 1994, it said.
Heavy bank interest payments also cut deep into the profits of state firms, it said.
An official survey covering the province's 70 big industrial groups showed bank interest payments from those firms rose 16.4 percent year-on-year to 26.16 billion yuan in 1996, it said.
Their liabilities-to-assets ratio averaged 63 percent, with 28 of them exceeding 70 percent and several topping 90 percent, the newspaper said.
Most debts were loans from state banks, with non-performing loans remaining at a high level, the newspaper added.
Welfare payments granted by state firms to employees surged 22.7 percent year-on-year in 1996 as a result of Beijing's policy of improving its social security system.
